Award.AwardTitle: BECS: Collaborative Research: Dynamical Networks and Collective Synchronization of Coupled Lasers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to conduct rigorous mathematical analysis of complex networks of interconnected dynamical systems, and apply the developed methods to control and collectively synchronize arrays of coupled semiconductor lasers. The main idea is based on the dynamical, rather than traditional static, description of the topology of a network, which allows to account for an analysis and evaluation of cumulative action of all three major ingredients that form a dynamical network: 1. local dynamics of elements of the network, 2. interactions between the elements of a network, 3. topology of the network. The project seeks an integration of the mathematical foundations with real world applications, and the developed mathematical machinery will be used to find synchronization conditions and to choose control parameters for synchronization of arrays of coupled semiconductor lasers.

The project will advance the fields of complex dynamical networks, nonlinear dynamics, and coupled semiconductor lasers, and provide theoretical guidance for laser experiments that may lead to significant technological impact in applications of semiconductor lasers such as space, fiber, and underwater communication, welding, cutting and others. The project integrates research projects with education activities through undergraduate and graduate education and research training, short course and workshop development, and outreach to K-12 education. The team also plans to recruit women engineering students and to retain them into careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arrays of semiconductor lasers provide one of very few experimental systems where one can explicitly experimentally observe and alter the dynamics of each separate element in the array, therefore a fair comparison between the mathematical results and experimental observations can be implemented. Synchronization patterns of linear identical nearest neighbor and globally coupled laser arrays have been extensively studied. However, the complex dynamics with a general coupling topology and decay coupling strength are not understood. In this collaborative project, a team of multidisciplinary faculty from Mathematics, Physics, and Engineering investigated general rigorous mathematical approach to the analysis of evolution of complex networks of interconnected dynamical systems with any graph of interactions, and applied the developed method to control coupled semiconductor lasers for collective synchronization. We have conducted rigorous mathematical analysis to networks of nonlinear oscillators and lasers, found synchronization conditions on network topology and coupling strength, and provided theoretical guidance on how to choose control parameters for synchronization.

Recent analytic study on collective behaviors of dynamical systems (such as concensus related work) is limited to linear or feedback linearizable systems, where the network topology is constrained by the spanning-tree type conditions and the interactions are mostly linear and static. Cooperative control of general nonlinear systems with arbitrary network topology and collective synchronization of higher-order nonlinear oscillators are open problems. This project integrates mathematical foundations with realworld applications, and new mathematical findings have been used to guide the design of a real engineered complex system that of both technological and theoretical importance. The project has advanced both fields in complex dynamical networks and coupled semiconductor lasers.

Semiconductor lasers are considered to be mostly energy efficient among all the lasers and combining single high power semiconductor lasers into arrays may result in much higher powers. The project has provided theoretical guidance for laser experiments that may lead to significant technological impact in applications of semiconductor lasers such as space and fiber communication, welding, cutting and fusion.

The project also integrates research projects with education activities through undergraduate and graduate education and research training, and outreach to K-12 education by partnering with the Stevens' Center for Innovation in Engineering and Science Education. The graduate students funded through the project benefited from the multi-disciplinary nature of the research, and had the opportunity to access the laser experimental facility at Oak Ridge National Laboratory. One of the graduate students supported by the project was a female engineering student.
